body: Ok, here's an update.
title: Java Time Zone is messed up

body: A coworker suggested I update JAVA_OPTS in my /etc/profile to include "-Duser.timezone=US/Pacific", which worked (I also saw CATALINA_OPTS, which I updated as well).

body: After some research I found that two practical approaches exists for this.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: One is using a tree structure just as the previous one.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: The drawback of this structure is that you need a ton of tweaking/hacks to get the multi-module reporting work well with Maven.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: Another downside is that in Subversion the standard trunk/tags/branches approach add even more complexity to the repository.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: The other approach uses a flat structure, where there are only one parent project and all the modules, submodules and parts-of-the-submodules are a direct child of the parent project.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: This approach works well for reporting and is easier in Subversion, however I feel I lose a bit of the structure this way.
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: Which way would you choose in the long term and why?
title: Repository layout for large Maven projects

body: Project Darkstar was the topic of the monthly JavaSIG meeting down at the Google offices in NYC last night.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: For those that don't know (probably everyone), Project Darkstar is a framework for massively multiplayer online games that attempts to take care of all of the "hard stuff."
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: The basic idea is that you write your game server logic in such a way that all operations are broken up into tiny tasks.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: You pass these tasks to the Project Darkstar framework which handles distributing them to a specific node in the cluster, any concurrency issues, and finally persisting the data.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Apparently doing this kind of thing is a much different problem for video games than it is for enterprise applications.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Jim Waldo, who gave the lecture, claims that MMO games have a DB read/write ratio of 50/50, whereas enterprise apps are more like 90% read, 10% write.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: He also claims that most existing MMOs keep everything in memory exlcusively, and only dump to a DB every 6 hours of so.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: This means if a server goes down, you would lose all of the work since the last DB dump.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Now, the project itself sounds really cool, but I don't think the industry will accept it.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: First, you have to write your server code in Java.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: The client code can be written in anything (Jim claims ActionScript 3 is the most popular, follow by C++), but the server stuff has to be Java.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Sounds good to me, but I really get the impression that everyone in the games industry hates Java.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Second, unlike other industries where developers prefer to use existing frameworks and libraries, the guys in the games industry seem to like to write everything themselves.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Not only that, they like to rewrite everything for every new game they produce.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Things are starting to change where developers are using Havok for physics, Unreal Engine 3 as their platform, etc., but for the most part it looks like everything is still proprietary.
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: So, are the guys at Project Darkstar just wasting their time?
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Can a general framework like this really work for complex games with the performance that is required?
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

body: Even if it does work, are game companies willing to use it?
title: Is Project Darkstar Realistic?

title: Do you write exceptions for specific issues or general exceptions?

body: My question is this: do you create a new Exception type for every one of these exceptions and then deal with them individually or do you create one MailException and then store something in the exception (something computer-readable, not the description text) that allows us to do different things based on what actually happened.
title: Do you write exceptions for specific issues or general exceptions?

body: Edit: As a clarification, the exceptions aren't for logs and what-not, this relates to how code reacts to them.

body: My code would want to react differently to each of these issues (mostly by changing the message returned to the client, but actual logic as well).
title: Do you write exceptions for specific issues or general exceptions?
